trans-unit.source: Deferred write; only applicable to files opened for shared access.

Deferred writes are cached in memory up to the limit specified by the dw_size option (see above). If the deferred-write buffer is full and you try to write still more deferred data, the buffer will be flushed. All buffered data will be written immediately, the buffer will be emptied, and the now-empty space will be used for future deferred writes.
trans-unit.target: Las escrituras diferidas se almacenan en la memoria caché hasta el límite especificado por la opción dw_size (ver más arriba). Si el búfer de escritura diferida está lleno e intenta escribir aún más datos diferidos, el búfer se vaciará. Todos los datos almacenados en búfer se escribirán inmediatamente, el búfer se vaciará y el espacio ahora vacío se utilizará para futuras escrituras diferidas.

trans-unit.source: Deflates the contents of $buffer . The buffer can either be a scalar or a scalar reference. When finished, $buffer will be completely processed (assuming there were no errors). trans-unit.source: Deletes a key/value pair in the hash. The value SV is removed from the hash, made mortal, and returned to the caller. The flags value will normally be zero; if set to G_DISCARD then NULL will be returned. NULL will also be returned if the key is not found. hash can be a valid precomputed hash value, or 0 to ask for it to be computed.

Deletes a key/value pair in the hash. The value SV is removed from the hash, made mortal, and returned to the caller. The flags value will normally be zero; if set to G_DISCARD then NULL will be returned. NULL will also be returned if the key is not found. hash can be a valid precomputed hash value, or 0 to ask for it to be computed.
trans-unit.target: Elimina un par clave / valor en el hash. El valor SV se elimina del hash, se convierte en mortal y se devuelve al llamador. El valor de las flags normalmente será cero; si se establece en G_DISCARD, se devolverá NULL. También se devolverá NULL si no se encuentra la clave. hash puede ser un valor hash precalculado válido, o 0 para solicitar que se calcule.

trans-unit.source: Deletes a key/value pair in the hash. The value's SV is removed from the hash, made mortal, and returned to the caller. The absolute value of klen is the length of the key. If klen is negative the key is assumed to be in UTF-8-encoded Unicode. The flags value will normally be zero; if set to G_DISCARD then NULL will be returned. NULL will also be returned if the key is not found.

Deletes a key/value pair in the hash. The value's SV is removed from the hash, made mortal, and returned to the caller. The absolute value of klen is the length of the key. If klen is negative the key is assumed to be in UTF-8-encoded Unicode. The flags value will normally be zero; if set to G_DISCARD then NULL will be returned. NULL will also be returned if the key is not found.
trans-unit.target: Elimina un par clave / valor en el hash. El SV del valor se elimina del hash, se convierte en mortal y se devuelve a la persona que llama. El valor absoluto de klen es la longitud de la clave. Si klen es negativo, se supone que la clave está en Unicode codificado en UTF-8. El valor de las flags normalmente será cero; si se establece en G_DISCARD, se devolverá NULL. También se devolverá NULL si no se encuentra la clave.

trans-unit.source: Deletes the element indexed by key from the array, makes the element mortal, and returns it. If flags equals G_DISCARD , the element is freed and null is returned. Perl equivalent: my $elem = delete($myarray[$idx]); for the non-G_DISCARD version and a void-context delete($myarray[$idx]); for the G_DISCARD version.
trans-unit.target: Elimina el elemento indexado por key de la matriz, hace que el elemento sea mortal y lo devuelve. Si flags es igual a G_DISCARD , el elemento se libera y se devuelve un valor nulo. Equivalente de Perl: my $elem = delete($myarray[$idx]); para la versión que no es G_DISCARD y una delete($myarray[$idx]); contexto vacío ($ myarray [$ idx]); para la versión G_DISCARD .

trans-unit.source: Deletes the element indexed by key from the array, makes the element mortal, and returns it. If flags equals G_DISCARD, the element is freed and NULL is returned. NULL is also returned if key is out of range.

Deletes the named file. Compared to Perl's unlink, DeleteFile has the advantage of not deleting read-only files. For some versions of Perl, unlink silently calls chmod whether it needs to or not before deleting the file so that files that you have protected by marking them as read-only are not always protected from Perl's unlink.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the current floating point rounding mode, rounds the argument either toward nearest (like "round"), toward zero (like "trunc"), downward (toward negative infinity), or upward (toward positive infinity) [C99].

Depending on the current floating point rounding mode, rounds the argument either toward nearest (like round), toward zero (like trunc), downward (toward negative infinity), or upward (toward positive infinity) [C99].
trans-unit.target: Dependiendo del modo de redondeo de punto flotante actual, redondea el argumento hacia el más cercano (como redondo ), hacia cero (como trunc ), hacia abajo (hacia infinito negativo) o hacia arriba (hacia infinito positivo) [C99].

trans-unit.source: Depending on the host operating system, the value of $^X may be a relative or absolute pathname of the perl program file, or may be the string used to invoke perl but not the pathname of the perl program file. Also, most operating systems permit invoking programs that are not in the PATH environment variable, so there is no guarantee that the value of $^X is in PATH. For VMS, the value may or may not include a version number.
trans-unit.target: Dependiendo del sistema operativo del host, el valor de $^X puede ser un nombre de ruta relativo o absoluto del archivo de programa perl, o puede ser la cadena utilizada para invocar perl pero no el nombre de ruta del archivo de programa perl. Además, la mayoría de los sistemas operativos permiten invocar programas que no están en la variable de entorno PATH, por lo que no hay garantía de que el valor de $^X esté en PATH. Para VMS, el valor puede incluir o no un número de versión.

trans-unit.source: Deprecated by Unicode. These are characters that expand to more than one character in the specified normalization form, but whether they actually take up more bytes or not depends on the encoding being used. For example, a UTF-8 encoded character may expand to a different number of bytes than a UTF-32 encoded character.
trans-unit.target: Desaprobado por Unicode.Se trata de caracteres que se expanden a más de un carácter en la forma de normalización especificada,pero el hecho de que ocupen o no más bytes depende de la codificación que se utilice.Por ejemplo,un carácter codificado en UTF-8 puede expandirse a un número diferente de bytes que un carácter codificado en UTF-32.

trans-unit.source: Deprecated function whose use raises a warning, and which is slated to be removed in a future Perl version. It is very similar to matching against qr/ ^ [[:alnum:]]+ $ /x , which you should convert to use instead. The function is deprecated because 1) it doesn't handle UTF-8 encoded strings properly; and 2) it returns TRUE even if the input is the empty string. The function return is always based on the current locale, whereas using locale rules is optional with the regular expression, based on pragmas in effect and pattern modifiers (see Character set modifiers in perlre and Which character set modifier is in effect? in perlre).
trans-unit.target: Función obsoleta cuyo uso genera una advertencia y que está programada para ser eliminada en una futura versión de Perl. Es muy similar a comparar con qr/ ^ [[:alnum:]]+ $ /x , que debe convertir para usar en su lugar. La función está obsoleta porque 1) no maneja correctamente cadenas codificadas en UTF-8; y 2) devuelve TRUE incluso si la entrada es la cadena vacía. El retorno de la función siempre se basa en la configuración regional actual, mientras que el uso de reglas de configuración regional es opcional con la expresión regular, basado en pragmas en vigor y modificadores de patrones (consulte Modificadores de juego de caracteres en perlre y ¿Qué modificador de juego de caracteres está en efecto? En perlre ).

trans-unit.source: Designed to be a method call, and to be overridden by a derived class (i.e. a class which has DynaLoader in its @ISA). The definition in DynaLoader itself returns 0, which produces standard behavior from dl_load_file().
trans-unit.target: Diseñado para ser una llamada de método,y para ser anulado por una clase derivada (es decir,una clase que tiene DynaLoader en su @ISA).La definición en el propio DynaLoader devuelve 0,lo que produce un comportamiento estándar de dl_load_file().

trans-unit.source: Destructors may not be called on objects if those objects still exist at global destruction time. If the destructors must be called, make sure there are no circular references and that nothing is referencing the objects before the program ends.

Destructors may not be called on objects if those objects still exist at global destruction time. If the destructors must be called, make sure there are no circular references and that nothing is referencing the objects, before the program ends.
trans-unit.target: Puede que no se recurra a los destructores de objetos si esos objetos todavía existen en el momento de la destrucción global.Si hay que llamar a los destructores,asegúrese de que no hay referencias circulares y que nada se refiere a los objetos,antes de que el programa termine.

trans-unit.source: Determines whether you have delete access to a file. If you do, candelete returns true. If you don't, or its argument isn't a legal file specification, candelete returns FALSE. Unlike other file tests, the argument to candelete must be a file name (not a FileHandle), and, since it's an XSUB, it's a list operator, so you need to be careful about parentheses. Both of these restrictions may be removed in the future if the functionality of candelete becomes part of the Perl core.

trans-unit.source: Devel::Peek
trans-unit.target: Devel::Peek

trans-unit.source: Devel::Peek - A data debugging tool for the XS programmer
trans-unit.target: Devel::Peek-Una herramienta de depuración de datos para el programador XS

trans-unit.source: Devel::Peek contains functions which allows raw Perl datatypes to be manipulated from a Perl script. This is used by those who do XS programming to check that the data they are sending from C to Perl looks as they think it should look. The trick, then, is to know what the raw datatype is supposed to look like when it gets to Perl. This document offers some tips and hints to describe good and bad raw data.
trans-unit.target: Devel::Peek contiene funciones que permiten manipular tipos de datos Perl en bruto desde un script Perl.Esto es usado por aquellos que hacen programación XS para comprobar que los datos que están enviando desde C a Perl se ven como ellos creen que deben verse.El truco,entonces,es saber cómo se supone que debe verse el tipo de datos en bruto cuando llega a Perl.Este documento ofrece algunos consejos y sugerencias para describir los buenos y malos datos en bruto.

trans-unit.source: Devel::Peek supplies a Dump() function which can dump a raw Perl datatype, and mstat("marker") function to report on memory usage (if perl is compiled with corresponding option). The function DeadCode() provides statistics on the data "frozen" into inactive CV . Devel::Peek also supplies SvREFCNT() which can query reference counts on SVs. This document will take a passive, and safe, approach to data debugging and for that it will describe only the Dump() function.
trans-unit.target: Devel :: Peek proporciona una función Dump() que puede volcar un tipo de datos Perl sin procesar, y una función mstat("marker") para informar sobre el uso de memoria (si Perl está compilado con la opción correspondiente). La función DeadCode () proporciona estadísticas sobre los datos "congelados" en CV inactivos . Devel :: Peek también proporciona SvREFCNT() que puede consultar recuentos de referencias en SV. Este documento adoptará un enfoque pasivo y seguro para la depuración de datos y para eso describirá solo la función Dump() .

trans-unit.source: Devel::Peek supplies a Dump() function which can dump a raw Perl datatype, and mstat("marker") function to report on memory usage (if perl is compiled with corresponding option). The function DeadCode() provides statistics on the data "frozen" into inactive CV. Devel::Peek also supplies SvREFCNT() which can query reference counts on SVs. This document will take a passive, and safe, approach to data debugging and for that it will describe only the Dump() function.

trans-unit.source: Devel::SelfStubber prints the stubs you need to put in the module before the __DATA__ token (or you can get it to print the entire module with stubs correctly placed). The stubs ensure that if a method is called, it will get loaded. They are needed specifically for inherited autoloaded methods.

trans-unit.source: Digest::SHA - Perl extension for SHA-1/224/256/384/512
trans-unit.target: Resumen::SHA-Extensión de Perl para SHA-1/224/256/384/512

trans-unit.source: Digest::SHA is a complete implementation of the NIST Secure Hash Standard. It gives Perl programmers a convenient way to calculate SHA-1, SHA-224, SHA-256, SHA-384, SHA-512, SHA-512/224, and SHA-512/256 message digests. The module can handle all types of input, including partial-byte data.
trans-unit.target: Digest::SHA es una implementación completa del Estándar de Seguridad de Hash del NIST.Le da a los programadores de Perl una forma conveniente de calcular los compendios de mensajes SHA-1,SHA-224,SHA-256,SHA-384,SHA-512,SHA-512/224 y SHA-512/256.El módulo puede manejar todo tipo de entradas,incluyendo datos de bytes parciales.

trans-unit.source: Digest::SHA is written in C for speed. If your platform lacks a C compiler, you can install the functionally equivalent (but much slower) Digest::SHA::PurePerl module.

trans-unit.target: Digest :: SHA está escrito en C para velocidad. Si su plataforma carece de un compilador C, puede instalar el módulo Digest :: SHA :: PurePerl funcionalmente equivalente (pero mucho más lento) .

trans-unit.source: Distribution metadata describe important properties of Perl distributions. Distribution building tools like Module::Build, Module::Install, ExtUtils::MakeMaker or Dist::Zilla should create a metadata file in accordance with this specification and include it with the distribution for use by automated tools that index, examine, package or install Perl distributions.
Distribution metadata should be serialized (as a hashref) as JSON-encoded data and packaged with distributions as the file

Distribution objects are normally distributions from the CPAN, but there is a slightly degenerate case for Distribution objects, too, of projects held on the local disk. These distribution objects have the same name as the local directory and end with a dot. A dot by itself is also allowed for the current directory at the time CPAN.pm was used. All actions such as make , test , and install are applied directly to that directory. This gives the command cpan . an interesting touch: while the normal mantra of installing a CPAN module without CPAN.pm is one of
trans-unit.target: Los objetos de distribución son normalmente distribuciones del CPAN, pero también hay un caso ligeramente degenerado para los objetos de distribución de proyectos que se mantienen en el disco local. Estos objetos de distribución tienen el mismo nombre que el directorio local y terminan con un punto. También se permite un punto por sí mismo para el directorio actual en el momento en que se utilizó CPAN.pm. Todas las acciones como make , test e install se aplican directamente a ese directorio. Esto da el comando cpan . un toque interesante: mientras que el mantra normal de instalar un módulo CPAN sin CPAN.pm es uno de

trans-unit.source: Divides $x by $y by doing floored division (F-division), where the quotient is the floored (rounded towards negative infinity) quotient of the two operands. In list context, returns the quotient and the remainder. The remainder is either zero or has the same sign as the second operand. In scalar context, only the quotient is returned.

Divides $x by $y by doing truncated division (T-division), where quotient is the truncated (rouneded towards zero) quotient of the two operands. In list context, returns the quotient and the remainder. The remainder is either zero or has the same sign as the first operand. In scalar context, only the quotient is returned.

trans-unit.source: Do not assume anything about the ordering of the characters. The lowercase letters may come before or after the uppercase letters; the lowercase and uppercase may be interlaced so that both "a" and "A" come before "b"; the accented and other international characters may be interlaced so that ä comes before "b". Unicode::Collate can be used to sort this all out.

Do not assume anything about the ordering of the characters. The lowercase letters may come before or after the uppercase letters; the lowercase and uppercase may be interlaced so that both "a" and "A" come before "b"; the accented and other international characters may be interlaced so that ä comes before "b". Unicode::Collate can be used to sort this all out.
trans-unit.target: No asumas nada sobre el orden de los personajes. Las letras minúsculas pueden ir antes o después de las mayúsculas; las minúsculas y las mayúsculas se pueden entrelazar para que tanto "a" como "A" vayan antes de "b"; los caracteres acentuados y otros caracteres internacionales pueden estar entrelazados de modo que ä vaya antes de "b". Unicode :: Collate se puede utilizar para resolver todo esto.

trans-unit.source: Do not assume that the alphabetic characters are encoded contiguously (in the numeric sense). There may be gaps. Special coding in Perl, however, guarantees that all subsets of qr/[A-Z]/, qr/[a-z]/, and qr/[0-9]/ behave as expected. tr/// behaves the same for these ranges. In patterns, any ranges specified with end points using the \N{...} notations ensures character set portability, but it is a bug in Perl v5.22, that this isn't true of tr///.
trans-unit.target: No asuma que los caracteres alfabéticos están codificados de forma contigua (en sentido numérico). Puede haber lagunas. Sin embargo, la codificación especial en Perl garantiza que todos los subconjuntos de qr/[A-Z]/ , qr/[a-z]/ y qr/[0-9]/ se comporten como se esperaba. tr/// comporta igual para estos rangos. En los patrones, cualquier rango especificado con puntos finales usando las notaciones \N{...} asegura la portabilidad del juego de caracteres, pero es un error en Perl v5.22 que esto no sea cierto para tr/// .

trans-unit.source: Do not assume that the alphabetic characters are encoded contiguously (in the numeric sense). There may be gaps. Special coding in Perl, however, guarantees that all subsets of qr/[A-Z]/, qr/[a-z]/, and qr/[0-9]/ behave as expected. tr/// behaves the same for these ranges. In patterns, any ranges specified with end points using the \N{...} notations ensures character set portability, but it is a bug in Perl v5.22 that this isn't true of tr///, fixed in v5.24.

trans-unit.source: Do not use either the bare result of pack("N", 10, 20, 30, 40) or bare v-strings (such as v10.20.30.40 ) to represent IPv4 addresses: both forms just pack the four bytes into network order. That this would be equal to the C language in_addr struct (which is what the socket code internally uses) is not guaranteed. To be portable use the routines of the Socket extension, such as inet_aton() , inet_ntoa() , and sockaddr_in() .
trans-unit.target: No utilice el resultado simple del pack("N", 10, 20, 30, 40) o cadenas v simples (como v10.20.30.40 ) para representar direcciones IPv4: ambas formas simplemente empaquetan los cuatro bytes en la red orden. No se garantiza que esto sea igual a la estructura in_addr del lenguaje C (que es lo que usa internamente el código de socket). Para ser portátil, use las rutinas de la extensión Socket , como inet_aton() , inet_ntoa() y sockaddr_in() .

All plain \b and \B boundary determinations look for word characters alone, not for non-word characters nor for string ends. Todos los llanos \b y \B determinaciones de frontera buscan caracteres de palabra solamente, no para caracteres no de palabras ni de extremos de cadena. Do note that the examples have been written by many different authors over a period of several decades. Styles and techniques will therefore differ, although some effort has been made to not vary styles too widely in the same sections. Do not consider one style to be better than others - "There's More Than One Way To Do It" is one of Perl's mottos. After all, in your journey as a programmer, you are likely to encounter different styles.
trans-unit.target: Obsérvese que los ejemplos han sido escritos por muchos autores diferentes a lo largo de varios decenios.Por consiguiente,los estilos y las técnicas serán diferentes,aunque se ha hecho un esfuerzo por no variar demasiado los estilos en las mismas secciones.No considere que un estilo es mejor que otros-"Hay más de una manera de hacerlo" es uno de los lemas de Perl.Después de todo,en su viaje como programador,es probable que se encuentre con diferentes estilos.

trans-unit.source: Does a fork(2) system call to create a new process running the same program at the same point. It returns the child pid to the parent process, 0 to the child process, or undef if the fork is unsuccessful. File descriptors (and sometimes locks on those descriptors) are shared, while everything else is copied. On most systems supporting fork(2), great care has gone into making it extremely efficient (for example, using copy-on-write technology on data pages), making it the dominant paradigm for multitasking over the last few decades.

Does a fork(2) system call to create a new process running the same program at the same point. It returns the child pid to the parent process, 0 to the child process, or undef if the fork is unsuccessful. File descriptors (and sometimes locks on those descriptors) are shared, while everything else is copied. On most systems supporting fork(), great care has gone into making it extremely efficient (for example, using copy-on-write technology on data pages), making it the dominant paradigm for multitasking over the last few decades.
trans-unit.target: Hace una llamada al sistema fork (2) para crear un nuevo proceso que ejecuta el mismo programa en el mismo punto. Devuelve el pid hijo al proceso padre, 0 al proceso hijo o undef si la bifurcación no tiene éxito. Los descriptores de archivo (y, a veces, bloqueos en esos descriptores) se comparten, mientras que todo lo demás se copia. En la mayoría de los sistemas que admiten fork (), se ha puesto mucho cuidado en hacerlo extremadamente eficiente (por ejemplo, utilizando tecnología de copia en escritura en páginas de datos), convirtiéndolo en el paradigma dominante para la multitarea en las últimas décadas.

trans-unit.source: Does a tree-walk of the syntax tree based at OP and calls METHOD on each op it visits. Each node is visited before its children. If walkoptree_debug (see below) has been called to turn debugging on then the method walkoptree_debug is called on each op before METHOD is called.
trans-unit.target: Realiza un recorrido por el árbol de sintaxis basado en OP y llama a METHOD en cada operación que visita. Cada nodo se visita antes que sus hijos. Si se ha llamado a walkoptree_debug (ver más abajo) para activar la depuración, se llama al método walkoptree_debug en cada operación antes de llamar a METHOD.

trans-unit.source: Does exactly the same thing as exec, except that a fork is done first and the parent process waits for the child process to exit. Note that argument processing varies depending on the number of arguments. If there is more than one argument in LIST, or if LIST is an array with more than one value, starts the program given by the first element of the list with arguments given by the rest of the list. If there is only one scalar argument, the argument is checked for shell metacharacters, and if there are any, the entire argument is passed to the system's command shell for parsing (this is /bin/sh -c on Unix platforms, but varies on other platforms). If there are no shell metacharacters in the argument, it is split into words and passed directly to execvp, which is more efficient. On Windows, only the system PROGRAM LIST syntax will reliably avoid using the shell; system LIST, even with more than one element, will fall back to the shell if the first spawn fails.

Does exactly the same thing as exec LIST , except that a fork is done first and the parent process waits for the child process to exit. Note that argument processing varies depending on the number of arguments. If there is more than one argument in LIST, or if LIST is an array with more than one value, starts the program given by the first element of the list with arguments given by the rest of the list. If there is only one scalar argument, the argument is checked for shell metacharacters, and if there are any, the entire argument is passed to the system's command shell for parsing (this is /bin/sh -c on Unix platforms, but varies on other platforms). If there are no shell metacharacters in the argument, it is split into words and passed directly to execvp , which is more efficient. On Windows, only the system PROGRAM LIST syntax will reliably avoid using the shell; system LIST , even with more than one element, will fall back to the shell if the first spawn fails.
trans-unit.target: Hace exactamente lo mismo que exec LIST , excepto que primero se realiza una bifurcación y el proceso padre espera a que salga el proceso hijo. Tenga en cuenta que el procesamiento de argumentos varía según el número de argumentos. Si hay más de un argumento en LIST, o si LIST es una matriz con más de un valor, inicia el programa dado por el primer elemento de la lista con argumentos dados por el resto de la lista. Si solo hay un argumento escalar, se verifica el argumento en busca de metacaracteres de shell, y si hay alguno, el argumento completo se pasa al shell de comandos del sistema para su análisis (esto es /bin/sh -c en plataformas Unix, pero varía en otras plataformas). Si no hay metacaracteres de shell en el argumento, se divide en palabras y se pasa directamente a execvp , que es más eficiente. En Windows, solo la sintaxis de la system PROGRAM LIST del sistema evitará de manera confiable el uso del shell; system LIST , incluso con más de un elemento, volverá al shell si falla el primer spawn.

Don't assume Unix filesystem access semantics: that read, write, and execute are all the permissions there are, and even if they exist, that their semantics (for example what do "r" , "w" , and "x" mean on a directory) are the Unix ones. The various Unix/POSIX compatibility layers usually try to make interfaces like chmod() work, but sometimes there simply is no good mapping.
trans-unit.target: No asuma Unix semántica de acceso a sistema de archivos: la lectura, escritura y ejecución son todos los permisos que hay, e incluso si es que existen, que su semántica (por ejemplo lo hacen "r" , "w" y "x" media en un directorio) son los de Unix. Las diversas capas de compatibilidad Unix / POSIX generalmente intentan hacer funcionar interfaces como chmod() , pero a veces simplemente no hay un buen mapeo.

trans-unit.source: Don't assume that the epoch starts at 00:00:00, January 1, 1970, because that is OS- and implementation-specific. It is better to store a date in an unambiguous representation. The ISO 8601 standard defines YYYY-MM-DD as the date format, or YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS (that's a literal "T" separating the date from the time). Please do use the ISO 8601 instead of making us guess what date 02/03/04 might be. ISO 8601 even sorts nicely as-is. A text representation (like "1987-12-18") can be easily converted into an OS-specific value using a module like Time::Piece (see "Date Parsing" in Time::Piece) or Date::Parse. An array of values, such as those returned by localtime, can be converted to an OS-specific representation using Time::Local.

Don't assume that the epoch starts at 00:00:00, January 1, 1970, because that is OS- and implementation-specific. It is better to store a date in an unambiguous representation. The ISO 8601 standard defines YYYY-MM-DD as the date format, or YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS (that's a literal "T" separating the date from the time). Please do use the ISO 8601 instead of making us guess what date 02/03/04 might be. ISO 8601 even sorts nicely as-is. A text representation (like "1987-12-18") can be easily converted into an OS-specific value using a module like Date::Parse . An array of values, such as those returned by localtime, can be converted to an OS-specific representation using Time::Local .
trans-unit.target: No asuma que la época comienza a las 00:00:00 del 1 de enero de 1970, porque eso es específico del sistema operativo y de la implementación. Es mejor almacenar una fecha en una representación inequívoca. El estándar ISO 8601 define YYYY-MM-DD como el formato de fecha, o YYYY-MM-DDTHH: MM: SS (que es una "T" literal que separa la fecha de la hora). Utilice la norma ISO 8601 en lugar de hacernos adivinar qué fecha podría ser el 02/03/04. ISO 8601 incluso se clasifica muy bien tal como está. Una representación de texto (como "1987-12-18") se puede convertir fácilmente en un valor específico del sistema operativo utilizando un módulo como Date::Parse . Una matriz de valores, como los devueltos por localtime , se puede convertir en una representación específica del sistema operativo utilizando Time::Local .

trans-unit.source: Don't be fooled into thinking that it is hard to create portable Perl code. It isn't. Perl tries its level-best to bridge the gaps between what's available on different platforms, and all the means available to use those features. Thus almost all Perl code runs on any machine without modification. But there are some significant issues in writing portable code, and this document is entirely about those issues.
trans-unit.target: No te engañes pensando que es difícil crear un código Perl portátil.No lo es.Perl intenta su mejor nivel para salvar las diferencias entre lo que está disponible en diferentes plataformas,y todos los medios disponibles para utilizar esas características.Por lo tanto,casi todo el código de Perl se ejecuta en cualquier máquina sin modificaciones.Pero hay algunos problemas significativos en la escritura de código portátil,y este documento trata enteramente de esos problemas.

trans-unit.source: Don't blame Perl. It's the same as in C. IEEE says we have to do this. Perl numbers whose absolute values are integers under 2**31 (on 32-bit machines) will work pretty much like mathematical integers. Other numbers are not guaranteed.

trans-unit.source: Don't require every module user to jump through the same hoops to achieve a simple result. You can always include optional parameters or routines for more complex or non-standard behaviour. If most of your users have to type a few almost identical lines of code when they start using your module, it's a sign that you should have made that behaviour a default. Another good indicator that you should use defaults is if most of your users call your routines with the same arguments.

trans-unit.source: Dotted Decimal Versions
Dotted-Decimal Versions
Dotted-Decimal version work sometimes
Dotted-Decimal versions

Dotted-decimal: bare v-strings (v1.2.3) and strings with more than one decimal point and a leading 'v' ("v1.2.3"); NOTE you can technically use a v-string or strings with a leading-v and only one decimal point (v1.2 or "v1.2"), but you will confuse both yourself and others.

Dotted-integer (also known as dotted-decimal) versions consist of positive integers separated by full stop characters (i.e. "dots", "periods" or "decimal points"). This are equivalent in format to Perl "v-strings", with some additional restrictions on form. They must be given in "normal" form, which has a leading "v" character and at least three integer components. To retain a one-to-one mapping with decimal versions, all components after the first should be restricted to the range 0 to 999. The final component may be separated by an underscore character instead of a period.

trans-unit.source: Doug MacEachern <dougm@osf.org>

Doug MacEachern has an article on embedding in Volume 1, Issue 4 of The Perl Journal ( http://www.tpj.com/ ). Doug is also the developer of the most widely-used Perl embedding: the mod_perl system (perl.apache.org), which embeds Perl in the Apache web server. Oracle, Binary Evolution, ActiveState, and Ben Sugars's nsapi_perl have used this model for Oracle, Netscape and Internet Information Server Perl plugins.

trans-unit.source: Due to an implementation glitch, the $SIG{__DIE__} hook is called even inside an eval(). trans-unit.target: Debido a un error de implementación, se llama al gancho $SIG{__DIE__} incluso dentro de eval() . Esta extraña acción a distancia puede $SIG{__DIE__} en una versión futura de modo que solo se llame a $ SIG {__ DIE__} si su programa está a punto de salir, como era la intención original. Cualquier otro uso está en desuso.

trans-unit.source: Due to an unfortunate bug in how given was implemented between Perl 5.10 and 5.16, under those implementations the version of $_ governed by given is merely a lexically scoped copy of the original, not a dynamically scoped alias to the original, as it would be if it were a foreach or under both the original and the current Perl 6 language specification. This bug was fixed in Perl 5.18. If you really want a lexical $_ , specify that explicitly, but note that my $_ is now deprecated and will warn unless warnings have been disabled:
trans-unit.target: Debido a un error desafortunado en cómo se implementó given entre Perl 5.10 y 5.16, bajo esas implementaciones, la versión de $_ gobernada por given es simplemente una copia con alcance léxico del original, no un alias con alcance dinámico al original, como sería si fuera un foreach o bajo la especificación del lenguaje Perl 6 original y actual. Este error se corrigió en Perl 5.18. Si realmente desea un $_ léxico , especifíquelo explícitamente, pero tenga en cuenta que my $_ ahora está en desuso y advertirá a menos que se hayan desactivado las advertencias:

trans-unit.source: Due to an unfortunate bug in how given was implemented between Perl 5.10 and 5.16, under those implementations the version of $_ governed by given is merely a lexically scoped copy of the original, not a dynamically scoped alias to the original, as it would be if it were a foreach or under both the original and the current Raku language specification. This bug was fixed in Perl 5.18 (and lexicalized $_ itself was removed in Perl 5.24).

Due to backwards compatibility, all filehandles resemble objects of class IO::Handle , or actually classes derived from that class. They actually aren't. Which means you can't derive your own class from IO::Handle and inherit those methods.
trans-unit.target: Debido a la compatibilidad con versiones anteriores, todos los identificadores de archivos se parecen a los objetos de la clase IO::Handle , o en realidad a las clases derivadas de esa clase. En realidad no lo son. Lo que significa que no puede derivar su propia clase de IO::Handle y heredar esos métodos.

Perl intenta cumplir con los estándares Open Group / IEEE para los resultados devueltos por atan2() , pero no puede forzar el problema si el sistema en el que se ejecuta Perl no lo permite. (Tru64, HP-UX 10.20)

trans-unit.source: Due to limitations of Perl subroutine call semantics, you cannot pass an array or hash. Prepend it with a \ to pass its reference instead. This will be remedied in time, now that Perl has subroutine prototypes. For now, you need to use the extended usage form, and prepend the name with a * to output it as a hash or array.
trans-unit.target: Debido a las limitaciones de la semántica de llamadas a subrutinas de Perl, no puede pasar una matriz o hash. Antepóngalo con \ para pasar su referencia en su lugar. Esto se solucionará con el tiempo, ahora que Perl tiene prototipos de subrutinas. Por ahora, debe usar el formulario de uso extendido y anteponer el nombre con un * para generarlo como un hash o una matriz.

Duplicate keys are entirely defined by the comparison function. In the case-insensitive example above, the keys: 'KEY' and 'key' would be considered duplicates, and assigning to the second one would overwrite the first. If duplicates are allowed for (with the R_DUP flag discussed below), only a single copy of duplicate keys is stored in the database --- so (again with example above) assigning three values to the keys: 'KEY', 'Key', and 'key' would leave just the first key: 'KEY' in the database with three values. For some situations this results in information loss, so care should be taken to provide fully qualified comparison functions when necessary. For example, the above comparison routine could be modified to additionally compare case-sensitively if two keys are equal in the case insensitive comparison:
trans-unit.target: Las claves duplicadas están totalmente definidas por la función de comparación.En el ejemplo anterior,que no distingue entre mayúsculas y minúsculas,las teclas "CLAVE" y "clave" se considerarían duplicadas,y al asignarlas a la segunda se sobrescribiría la primera.Si se permiten los duplicados (con el indicador R_DUP que se discute más adelante),sólo se almacena una única copia de las claves duplicadas en la base de datos ---así que (de nuevo con el ejemplo anterior)asignar tres valores a las claves:'KEY','Key' y 'key' dejaría sólo la primera clave:'KEY' en la base de datos con tres valores.Para algunas situaciones esto resulta en una pérdida de información,por lo que se debe tener cuidado de proporcionar funciones de comparación totalmente cualificadas cuando sea necesario.Por ejemplo,la rutina de comparación anterior podría modificarse para comparar adicionalmente las mayúsculas y minúsculas si dos claves son iguales en la comparación insensible a las mayúsculas y minúsculas:

During recent history, data is moved around a computer in 8-bit chunks, often called "bytes" but also known as "octets" in standards documents. trans-unit.source: Dynamic loading

Dynamic loading is required if you want to use XS modules from CPAN (like DBI (and DBD's), JSON::XS, and Text::CSV_XS) or update CORE modules from CPAN with newer versions (like Encode) without rebuilding all of the perl binary.

Dynamic scoping works over a dynamic scope, making variables visible throughout the rest of the block in which they are first used and in any subroutines that are called by the rest of the block. Dynamically scoped variables can have their values temporarily changed (and implicitly restored later) by a local operator. (Compare lexical scoping.) Used more loosely to mean how a subroutine that is in the middle of calling another subroutine “contains” that subroutine at runtime.
trans-unit.target: El alcance dinámico funciona en un alcance dinámico , haciendo que las variables sean visibles en el resto del bloque en el que se utilizan por primera vez y en cualquier subrutina que el resto del bloque llame. Las variables de ámbito dinámico pueden tener sus valores modificados temporalmente (y restaurados implícitamente más tarde) por un operador local . (Compare el alcance léxico ). Se usa de manera más vaga para referirse a cómo una subrutina que está en medio de llamar a otra subrutina "contiene" esa subrutina en tiempo de ejecución .

trans-unit.source: Dynamic scoping works over a dynamic scope, making variables visible throughout the rest of the block in which they are first used and in any subroutines that are called by the rest of the block. Dynamically scoped variables can have their values temporarily changed (and implicitly restored later) by a local operator. (Compare lexical scoping.) Used more loosely to mean how a subroutine that is in the middle of calling another subroutine “contains” that subroutine at runtime.
Dynamically load $filename, which must be the path to a shared object or library. An opaque 'library reference' is returned as a handle for the loaded object. Returns undef on error.
trans-unit.target: Cargar dinámicamente $nombre del archivo,que debe ser la ruta a un objeto o biblioteca compartida.Una "referencia de biblioteca" opaca es devuelta como un "handle" para el objeto cargado.Devuelve undef en el error.

trans-unit.source: Dynamically load C libraries into Perl code
trans-unit.target: Cargar dinámicamente las bibliotecas C en código Perl

trans-unit.source: Dynamically unload $libref, which must be an opaque 'library reference' as returned from dl_load_file. Returns one on success and zero on failure. This function is optional and may not necessarily be provided on all platforms.
trans-unit.target: Descargue dinámicamente $libref,que debe ser una 'referencia de biblioteca' opaca como la devuelta del dl_load_file.Devuelve uno en el éxito y cero en el fracaso.Esta función es opcional y no necesariamente se proporciona en todas las plataformas.

trans-unit.source: E<...> may freely appear in any formatting code (other than in another E<...> or in an Z<>). That is, "X<The E<euro>1,000,000 Solution>" is valid, as is "L<The E<euro>1,000,000 Solution|Million::Euros>".
trans-unit.target: E <...> puede aparecer libremente en cualquier código de formato (salvo en otro E <...> o en Z <>). Es decir, "X <La solución E <euro> 1,000,000>" es válida, al igual que "L <La solución E <euro> 1,000,000 | Millones :: Euros>".

trans-unit.source: EXAMPLE: $ perl -e"exit 44;" Non-hushed error exit %SYSTEM-F-ABORT, abort DCL message $ show sym $STATUS $STATUS == "%X0000002C"
trans-unit.target: EJEMPLO:$ perl -e "exit 44;" Non-hushed error exit %SYSTEM-F-ABORT,abortar el mensaje de DCL $ show sym $STATUS $STATUS =="%X0000002C"

trans-unit.source: EXAMPLE: if ($quiet_exit) { vmsish::hushed(1); } print "Sssshhhh...I'm hushed...\n" if vmsish::hushed(); exit 44;
trans-unit.target: EJEMPLO:si ($quiet_exit){vmsish::silenciado(1);}escriba "Sssshhhh...estoy silenciado...\n" si vmsish::silenciado();salida 44;

trans-unit.source: EXAMPLE: use vmsish 'hushed'; # turn on hushed flag use Carp; # Carp compiled hushed exit 44; # will be hushed croak('I die'); # will be hushed no vmsish 'hushed'; # turn off hushed flag exit 44; # will not be hushed croak('I die2'): # WILL be hushed, croak was compiled hushed
trans-unit.target: EJEMPLO:usar vmsish "silencioso";#encender bandera silenciosa usar Carpa;#Carpa compilada salida silenciosa 44;#será croak silencioso('I die');#no será croak silencioso vmsish "silencioso";#apagar bandera silenciosa salida 44;#no será croak silencioso('I die2'):#Será silenciado,el croak fue compilado en silencio
